chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A unifying reform would keep states administering elections but ensure the presidency tracks the broadest voter support by softening winner‑take‑all: allow states to allocate electors proportionally (or by districts drawn by independent commissions) and add a national popular‑vote backstop only in close or disputed outcomes. Any shift should come with enforceable national baselines—paper ballots or voter‑verified records, routine risk‑limiting audits, uniform recount triggers, and stronger penalties for faithless electors. Implement the changes on a clear timeline with pilot adoption and public reporting so voters can build confidence before the rules become universal.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Pursue an incremental reform that keeps states central to election administration while reducing winner‑take‑all distortions so outcomes better match voter intent. Allow states to adopt proportional or district‑based elector allocation (with independent redistricting and anti‑gerrymandering safeguards) and/or join a National Popular Vote compact, paired with strong protections against faithless electors. Any structural change should be backed by nationwide baseline standards for ballot access, auditable paper trails, routine post‑election audits, and clear recount triggers to build cross‑partisan confidence and reduce litigation.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Keep the Electoral College’s state-based framework, but reduce winner-take-all distortions so more votes matter in every state by encouraging proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors with strong protections against gerrymandering and faithless electors. As an additional backstop, allow states to opt into a national popular-vote compact once clear, audited nationwide standards for ballot access, paper trails, recount triggers, and post-election audits are in place. Phase reforms in with pilot periods and transparent benchmarks so rural and small-state voters keep a meaningful voice while outcomes more reliably match the overall will of voters.
